Massachusetts General Laws Chapter 208,.proposition: The Plaintiff respectfully requests that the Court enter an order modifying the existing custody arrangement to reflect the aforementioned changes in the best interests of the child.

Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.proposition: The Plaintiff respectfully requests that the Court enter an order modifying the existing custody arrangement to reflect the aforementioned changes in the best interests of the child.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.support_reasoning: The proposition concerns a request that the court modify an existing custody arrangement based on changed circumstances and the best interests of the child. Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas is an appeal from an original divorce and custody judgment, focusing on initial custody allocation and removal of the children to Greece, not on a later modification proceeding. Although the case discusses that custody and removal decisions must be based on the best interests of the child, it does not address standards or procedure for modifying an existing custody order, so it does not directly support the specific proposition cited.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.relevant_excerpt: “The Massachusetts removal statute, G. L. c. 208, § 30 (1984 ed.), provides that… ‘unless the court upon cause shown otherwise orders.’ The words ‘upon cause shown’ mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child… and thus the central question in this case is how these ‘best interests’ are to be determined. Cases involving removal of a child from the jurisdiction present difficult choices… An evaluation of the best interests of the child requires attention to whether the quality of the child’s life may be improved by the change…”

Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 690 (1996).proposition: The Plaintiff respectfully requests that the Court enter an order modifying the existing custody arrangement to reflect the aforementioned changes in the best interests of the child.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 690 (1996).case_name: O'Brien v. New England Telephone & Telegraph Co.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 690 (1996).support_reasoning: The opinion concerns wrongful termination, implied employment contracts based on a personnel manual, intentional interference with contractual relations, and the need to exhaust a contractual grievance procedure. It does not address child custody, modification of custody orders, or the best interests of the child standard. Therefore, it provides no authority for a request to modify a custody arrangement in the child’s best interests.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 690 (1996).relevant_excerpt: We see no justification for treating differently an employee asserting rights under a personnel manual that contains a grievance procedure where none of the limited exceptions to the exhaustion requirement, noted in the cited cases, applies.

Bower v. Bournay-Bower, 469 Mass. 690 (2.proposition: The Plaintiff respectfully requests that the Court enter an order modifying the existing custody arrangement to reflect the aforementioned changes in the best interests of the child.
Bower v. Bournay-Bower, 469 Mass. 690 (2.support_reasoning: The proposition concerns a party’s request that the court enter an order modifying an existing custody arrangement based on changes in the child’s best interests. Bower v. Bournay-Bower does not address standards or procedures for a party’s motion to modify custody, nor does it authorize or discuss the form of relief requested in the proposition. Instead, it addresses the limits of a judge’s inherent authority to appoint a parenting coordinator and the impermissible delegation of judicial decision-making, referencing the statutory modification standard only to contrast it with the unlawful delegation in that case.
Bower v. Bournay-Bower, 469 Mass. 690 (2.relevant_excerpt: “By statute, if a party seeks a modification of a final judgment of divorce, a judge may make a judgment modifying his or her earlier judgment provided the judge finds that ‘a material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties has occurred and the judgment of modification is necessary in the best interests of the children.’ G. L. c. 208, § 28. No such standard governs the parent coordinator in the order at issue in this case.”

Morales v. Morales, 431 Mass. 794 (2000).proposition: The Plaintiff respectfully requests that the Court enter an order modifying the existing custody arrangement to reflect the aforementioned changes in the best interests of the child.
Morales v. Morales, 431 Mass. 794 (2000).case_name: Wakefield Teachers Ass'n v. School Committee
Morales v. Morales, 431 Mass. 794 (2000).support_reasoning: The case concerns whether a school superintendent’s disciplinary report about a teacher is exempt from disclosure under the Massachusetts public records law. It does not address child custody, family law, or standards for modifying custody orders based on the best interests of the child. Therefore, it provides no authority for a request to modify an existing custody arrangement.
Morales v. Morales, 431 Mass. 794 (2000).relevant_excerpt: We consider in this case whether a disciplinary decision and report (report) of the superintendent of Wakefield public schools (superintendent) regarding the performance of a Wakefield public school teacher is exempt from disclosure under the public records law, G. L. c. 66, § 10, pursuant to G. L. c. 4, § 7, Twenty-sixth (c). We hold that the report, which resulted in the teacher’s four-week suspension, constitutes part of the teacher’s “personnel ... file[ ] or information,” and is exempt from disclosure.

Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (1992).proposition: The Plaintiff respectfully requests that the Court enter an order modifying the existing custody arrangement to reflect the aforementioned changes in the best interests of the child.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (1992).support_reasoning: The proposition is a generic request for modification of custody based on the child’s best interests. Mason v. Coleman deals specifically with the standard for *removal* from the Commonwealth under G.L. c. 208, § 30 in a joint physical custody context, not with a general motion to modify an existing custody arrangement. While the opinion repeatedly applies a best-interests analysis, it does not establish any rule about when or how a court should enter an order modifying custody as requested by a party, so it does not directly support the cited proposition.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (1992).relevant_excerpt:
“We conclude that in such a situation ‘cause shown’ pursuant to G. L. c. 208, § 30, means a showing that removal is in the ‘best interests’ of the children taking into account all the circumstances and weighing the factors as described below.
On the facts in this case, the judge appropriately considered the ‘best interests’ of the children, and did not abuse her discretion in concluding that removal of the children would not serve their best interests.”

Custody of Polain, 791 N.E.2d 598 (2003).proposition: The Plaintiff respectfully requests that the Court enter an order modifying the existing custody arrangement to reflect the aforementioned changes in the best interests of the child.
Custody of Polain, 791 N.E.2d 598 (2003).support_reasoning: The cited opinion is a criminal case about aggravated battery with a firearm and evidentiary/sentencing issues. It does not involve child custody, family law, or standards for modifying custody based on the best interests of the child. Therefore, it provides no legal authority for a proposition requesting modification of a custody arrangement in the child’s best interests.
Custody of Polain, 791 N.E.2d 598 (2003).relevant_excerpt: Defendant's next contention is that the State did not prove him guilty beyond a reasonable doubt of the crime of aggravated battery with a firearm. In reviewing the sufficiency of the evidence used to convict a defendant, a reviewing court does not reweigh the evidence or determine anew the defendant's guilt. Rather, the reviewing court, viewing all of the evidence in the light most favorable to the prosecution, determines whether any rational trier of fact could have found the essential elements of the crime beyond a reasonable doubt.

Bowring v. Reid, 152 N.E.2d 609 (2017).proposition: The Plaintiff respectfully requests that the Court enter an order modifying the existing custody arrangement to reflect the aforementioned changes in the best interests of the child.

Tamas v. Tamas, 810 N.E.2d 819 (2008).proposition: The Plaintiff respectfully requests that the Court enter an order modifying the existing custody arrangement to reflect the aforementioned changes in the best interests of the child.
Tamas v. Tamas, 810 N.E.2d 819 (2008).support_reasoning: The opinion is a Massachusetts criminal OUI appeal dealing with sufficiency of the evidence and prosecutorial misconduct in closing argument. It does not involve family law, custody, or any standard for modifying a custody arrangement based on the child’s best interests. Therefore, it provides no authority for a request to modify custody in the best interests of the child.
Tamas v. Tamas, 810 N.E.2d 819 (2008).relevant_excerpt: To convict the defendant of operating a motor vehicle while under the influence of intoxicating liquor, the Commonwealth was required to prove that the defendant (1) operated a vehicle, (2) on a public way, (3) while under the influence of alcohol. Commonwealth v. O’Connor, 420 Mass. 630, 631 (1995). The only element disputed by the defendant is whether he was under the influence of alcohol.

Graziano v. Graziano, 139 N.E.2d 693 (20.proposition: The Plaintiff respectfully requests that the Court enter an order modifying the existing custody arrangement to reflect the aforementioned changes in the best interests of the child.
Graziano v. Graziano, 139 N.E.2d 693 (20.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns a procedural motion to dismiss an appeal for failure to comply with an appellate rule and how to construe a notice of appeal. It does not address child custody, modification of custody orders, or best interests of the child standards. Therefore, it cannot provide authority for a request to modify an existing custody arrangement based on the child’s best interests.
Graziano v. Graziano, 139 N.E.2d 693 (20.relevant_excerpt: "Submitted on motion of the appellee seeking an order dismissing the appeal for failure to comply with Rule VII. The record reveals that the notice of appeal does not specify the type of appeal being pursued, but merely gives ‘Notice of Appeal.’ We must give a liberal construction to said notice and treat it as an appeal on questions of law and law and fact... We note that the action is one for damages for false arrest."

Sweeny v. Sweeny, 654 N.E.2d 976 (1998).proposition: The Plaintiff respectfully requests that the Court enter an order modifying the existing custody arrangement to reflect the aforementioned changes in the best interests of the child.
